poem:
Striking Silence

At St Thomas', silence swells,  
white coats linger, but do not clash –  
their absence a cry, unheard.  
The pulse of protest softly fades  
beneath Parliament's watchful gaze;  
only whispers tread the bridge  
where care once walked.  
  
Doctors' hands, now stilled,  
speak – though silence fills the air,  
in quiet resolve they stand.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The right wants to kill off the NHS. Striking doctors are playing into their hands | Polly Toynbee There were no pickets when I set out at the weekend to talk to striking doctors. Not even at St Thomas’ hospital, a prime site opposite the Houses of Parliament, or at Guy’s at London Bridge. “It’s a bit sparse,” said the duty officer from the British Medical Association, the doctors’ union. The British Medical Journal (owned". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
